practice_cycles.short_explanation_for_cycle: This phase is necessary because moving from a beginner status to an intermediate one in React Native requires you to move beyond simple web-like layouts and into the complexities of mobile-specific architecture and environment configuration. By establishing a solid understanding of how components render on mobile versus the web, you allow your skills to scale without the frustration of debugging basic layout issues later on. Your progress depends on mastering the core primitive components and how they interact within the mobile ecosystem before you tackle more complex state management or native module integrations.

weekly_loop.primary_activity: Building static clones of popular mobile app UI screens using View, Text, and Image components.
weekly_loop.secondary_activity: Refactoring layouts to use Flexbox specifically for iOS and Android screen variations.

difficulty_profile.comfortable: Mapping data to basic lists using FlatList.
difficulty_profile.challenging: Achieving pixel-perfect designs across different device aspect ratios.

objective: Zero layout errors on both iOS and Android emulators
subjective: Feeling intuitive about when to use View vs ScrollView
Reduced reliance on documentation for Flexbox properties

practice_cycles.short_explanation_for_cycle: This phase is necessary because intermediate proficiency is defined by your ability to manage multi-screen flows and handle real-world data effectively. You must transition from static views to dynamic applications where user intent dictates the interface. By focusing on navigation patterns and state synchronization across screens, you ensure that your applications feel like native experiences rather than just a collection of disconnected mobile web pages. Your growth in this period bridges the gap between simple UI work and functional application development.

weekly_loop.primary_activity: Implementing Stack and Tab navigation within a multi-screen prototype.
weekly_loop.secondary_activity: Integrating Fetch or Axios to populate screens with data from a public API.

difficulty_profile.challenging: Managing complex state transitions and deep linking configurations.

objective: Successful data retrieval and error handling for API calls
subjective: Clarity on when to use local state versus global context

objective: Time taken to resolve a Red Screen of Death (RSOD)
Number of unique React Native core components utilized in a single project
Application bundle size and load time on a physical device
subjective: Comfort level with mobile-first constraints compared to web
Perceived ease of debugging asynchronous state updates
Ability to explain the difference between the bridge and JSI

architect_notes: The 9-hour weekly commitment allows for three 3-hour sessions, which is better for deep work in mobile development than daily 1-hour slots due to environment boot times.
Initial focus remains on Expo to minimize the high dropout risk associated with native Android Studio/Xcode configuration.
Transition to intermediate level is marked by the shift from 'building screens' to 'architecting flows'.

practice_logs.activity: Building static clones of popular mobile app UI
Refactoring layouts to use Flexbox specifically for iOS and Android screen variations.
Built a UI interface with react native
Refactored layouts to use Flexbox specifically for iOS and Android screen variations.
Learn mobile responsiveness with react native

friction_signals: Extreme difficulty variance (10 vs 1) between related layout tasks
Session duration (80 minutes) is significantly shorter than the 180-minute deep-work recommendation
Primary activity (UI cloning) reported at maximum difficulty (10/10)
positive_signals: Task selection matches the primary and secondary activities defined in Cycle 1
Stable fatigue levels (4-5) despite high perceived difficulty

analysis_notes: Activities are perfectly aligned with the Cycle 1 focus on Foundational Primitives and Layout.
A significant 'friction signal' exists in the 10/10 difficulty rating for the primary activity, indicating the user is at the ceiling of their current capability.
The 80-minute total duration deviates from the architect's note recommending 3-hour sessions for deep work.
The 1/10 difficulty for Flexbox refactoring suggests a high comfort level with the secondary activity, contrasting sharply with the 10/10 primary activity.
